title: 103_hr4476
content: The Act titled "National Park System Reform Act of 1994" includes a section on the preparation of a National Park System Plan. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 mandates the preparation of a National Park System Plan by the Secretary of the Interior. The plan will define goals, criteria for resource inclusion, representation of national heritage, and identification of appropriate aspects for preservation. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 mandates the preparation of a National Park System Plan by the Secretary of the Interior, which includes defining goals, criteria for resource inclusion, representation of national heritage, identification of appropriate aspects for preservation, and the role of the National Park Service in various preservation efforts and outdoor recreation opportunities. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 requires the Secretary of the Interior to develop a National Park System Plan, which involves defining areas within the system, consulting with various stakeholders, and submitting the plan to Congress within a specified timeframe. SEC. 102. MANAGEMENT REVIEW OF NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM. The Secretary will review the National Park System to determine if there are better management alternatives, considering factors like duplication, resource representation, cost, and visitor accessibility. A report will list areas where National Park Service management should be modified or terminated. The Secretary will review the National Park System to assess management alternatives based on factors like cost, visitor accessibility, and resource protection. Recommendations will be made for areas where National Park Service management should be changed or terminated, with consultation from various stakeholders. Feasible alternatives to protect resources and ensure public access will be identified before any changes are implemented. The Secretary will consult with various stakeholders, including Federal land managing agencies, State and local officials, and the National Park System Advisory Board, to develop recommendations for modifications or termination of National Park Service management. The report will be transmitted to Congress within 1 year, containing suggestions for alternative management by entities other than the National Park Service. SEC. 103. NATIONAL PARK SYSTEM REVIEW COMMISSION. Establishment of Commission: If the Secretary fails to transmit the report within the specified 1-year period, a National Park System Review Commission will be established to review existing units for potential management modifications or terminations. The Commission will submit a report to the House Natural Resources Committee and the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee within one year, listing areas where management changes are recommended. Feasible alternatives to National Park Service management will be identified for areas of national significance before inclusion on the list. The Commission shall suggest alternative management for listed areas by entities other than the National Park Service. Feasible alternatives to National Park Service management for areas of national significance must be identified before inclusion on the list. The Commission, consisting of 7 members familiar with the National Park System, will consult with various agencies and organizations, including opportunities for public review and comment. Three members, including the Director of the National Park Service, will be appointed by the Secretary, and two members will be appointed by the Speaker of the United States House of Representatives. The Commission, consisting of 7 members familiar with the National Park System, will suggest alternative management for listed areas by entities other than the National Park Service. Members will be appointed by the Secretary, Speaker of the United States House of Representatives, and President Pro Tem of the United States Senate. The Commission will elect a chair from among its members, fill vacancies promptly, and meet quarterly with a simple majority constituting a quorum. Members serve without compensation. The Commission, once established, will meet quarterly with a simple majority constituting a quorum. Members serve without compensation but are entitled to travel expenses. The Commission will terminate 90 days after submitting the report to Congress. It may hire staff, with a limitation on National Park Service employees, and can request staff from other agencies. The Commission may hire staff to carry out its responsibilities, with a limit on National Park Service employees. It can also request personnel from other federal agencies and procure temporary services as needed. The Commission has the power to hold public hearings, make bylaws, rules, and regulations to fulfill its duties. The Commission has the power to hold public hearings, make bylaws, rules, and regulations, and receive information from the Secretary relevant to its duties. SEC. 201. STUDY OF NEW PARK SYSTEM AREAS. Section 8 of the Act of August 18, 1970 is amended to include a new subsection (b) requiring the Secretary to submit a list of areas recommended for study for potential inclusion in the National Park System to the appropriate committees annually. The Secretary must annually submit a list of areas recommended for study for potential inclusion in the National Park System to the House Committee on Natural Resources and the Senate Committee on Energy and Natural Resources. Consideration is given to areas with national significance, suitability, and feasibility, with special attention to themes, sites, and resources not adequately represented in the National Park System. No new studies for potential inclusion in the National Park System can be initiated without specific authorization from Congress. The National Park System Reform Act of 1994 prohibits new studies for potential inclusion in the National Park System without specific authorization from Congress. The Secretary must complete each study within 3 fiscal years of enactment. The Secretary must complete studies for potential additions to the National Park System within 3 fiscal years of specific legislation enactment. Studies must consider national significance, resources, recreational opportunities, and feasibility. Factors such as resource rarity, integrity, threats, and existing protections are also evaluated. Each study for potential additions to the National Park System must consider factors such as resource rarity, threats, public use potential, costs, and public support. The study should also evaluate whether National Park Service management or alternative protection is appropriate for the area, and identify the most effective way to protect resources and provide for public enjoyment. The Director of the National Park Service conducts studies to determine the most effective management option for areas with significant resources. The Secretary submits a list of areas for potential addition to the National Park System based on factors like resource values, threats, and cost considerations. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 28, 1994.
